title: Some integer sequences based on derangements

title_detail.value: Some integer sequences based on derangements

summary:
Sequences whose terms are equal to the number of functions with specified
properties are considered. Properties are based on the notion of derangements
in a more general sense. Several sequences which generalize the standard notion
of derangements are thus obtained. These sequences generate a number of integer
sequences from the well-known Sloane's encyclopedia.

Abstract
Sequences whose terms are equal to the number of functions with
specified properties are considered. Properties are based on the notion
of derangements in a more general sense. Several sequences which
generalize the standard notion of derangements are thus obtained.
These sequences generate a number of integer sequences from the wellknown Sloane's encyclopedia.

Let A be an m × n rectangular area whose elements are from a set Ω, and
let c1 , . . . , cm be from Ω. Following the paper [1], we call each column of
A which is equal to [c1 , . . . , cm ]T an i-column of A. As usual by [n] will
be denoted the set {1, 2, . . . , n}, and by |X| the number of elements of a
finite set X. Mutually disjoint subsets are called blocks. A block with k
elements is called k-block. We also denote by n(m) the falling factorials, that
is, n(m) = n(n − 1) * * * (n − m + 1). Stirling numbers of the second kind will
be denoted by S(m, n).
